 - 1 - 1. SECTOR BACKGROUND AND ISSUES A. BACKGROUND 1.1 China has achieved well known gains in education. With an enrollment of 132 million pupils and 5.6 million teachers in about 668,700 primary schools, China runs the largest primary school system in the world. At the junior secondary level there are 67,000 schools with an enrollment of 46.6 million pupils and 2.8 million teachers. In 1995, overall national net enrollment rates for the first nine years of schooling were 98.5 percent of the 6-11 age cohort enrolled in primary education, and more than 78.4 percent of the 12-15 age cohort in junior secondary schools. Of primary graduates, 90.8 percent went on to middle schools (regular or vocational). Almost 98.2 percent of all school-age girls have been enrolled in primary education. A significant consequence of these high enrollment figures is the high literacy rates: 80 percent for those above 15 years of age and about 93 percent among those between 15 and 25 years of age. The projected figures for 2000 are 135 million pupils at primary level and 55 million at junior secondary level. 1.2 Global figures, though indicative of substantial progress, tend to mask disparities in basic education development, with noticeable imbalances in the availability of educational services between the economically advanced and underdeveloped regions. Generally, urban and coastal areas have achieved the goal of nine-year basic education, but many poor, sparsely-populated and remote areas have not achieved the primary education targets. Schooling in poor counties is marked by poor attendance and high repetition and drop-out rates. Although net enrollment rates for primary school-age children in several autonomous regions exceed the national average of 98.5, five provinces-Gansu, Guizhou, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan-and three autonomous regions-Ningxia, Tibet and Xinjiang-lag far behind. Regional disparities are even more conspicuous in completion rates, i.e., the proportion of children entering first grade who eventually graduate from primary school. While the national average for the completion rate in 1991-92 was estimated at 91 percent, it ranged between 78.6 percent in Jiangxi Province and 99.7 percent in Beijing. 1.3 Among the deprived sections of the population, minorities and girls and women continue to be more disadvantaged. For example, a study of 25 minority counties shows that the gross enrollment rate of school aged minority children was 20 percentage points lower than the national mean, with female enrollment particularly low. Facilities for basic education are equally available for both boys and girls, yet there is a significantly lower level of utilization of facilities by girls. Almost half the rural population is literate or semi-literate, the illiteracy rate for women being 70 percent. Enrollment rates for girls in minority areas can reach 20 to 30 percent less than for boys. The number of female teachers in rural minority areas tends to be about one third of that of male teachers.
 -2 - B. SECTOR REFORM AGENDA 1.4 Educational development is a major instrument in China's drive for modernization to the end of this century and the early stage of the 21st century. Educational reforms and development, responsive to the changing human capital demands of the growing economy, were encapsulated in a series of policy and legal documents, such as "Decision to Reform the Educational Structure" (1985), "Compulsory Education Law" (1986), "Outline for Reform and Development of Education" (1993), and "Education Law" (1995). The current reforms relevant to basic education focus on the following areas: (a) the provision of Nine Years' Compulsory Education for all school-age children; (b) the development of vocational and technical education at the secondary and postsecondary levels; (c) the strengthening of education management at all levels by strengthening the role of principals and local authorities in the design of the reforms, and transferring the responsibility for providing basic education to local governments under the central government's policy guidance and financial support; (d) the great increase of investment in basic education by the governments at all levels; (e) the continuous improvement and gradual standardization of school operational conditions; (f) the enhancement of teachers quality by further strengthening of teachers' education and training. The State Education Commission (SEdC), created in June 1986 as- the successor to the Ministry of Education (MOE) and responsible nationally for policy, budgeting and coordination of this sector, therefore has the mission of overseeing the above reforms at the national level. C. MAJOR ISSUES AND CONSTRAINTS 1.5 The goal of universalization of basic education in poor counties has to contend with a number of key sector issues and constraints, many of which are due to the diversity of conditions in different parts of China. Rural poverty exacerbates such conditions. Further, the reforms call for a number of administrative changes for which local management capacity will have to be developed. Weak educational outcomes signal low returns to investment and a failure to capture the significant benefits in poverty reduction, economic development and social returns that basic education has been shown to generate internationally. This section is based on extensive Bank Group economic and sector work' completed for the first basic education project (Education Development in Poor Provinces (CR. 2339-CHA) (EDPP) and work carried out by major Chinese research institutions and scholars, and economic and financial analyses, including household education spending surveys carried out during the Third and the current proposed Fourth Basic Education Projects (BEIV). With ranging emphases, all four basic education projects have been designed to address the following issues and constraints. A detailed discussion of these issues can be found in China: Provincial Education Sector Planning and Finance, Sector Study. The World Bank, China and Mongolia Departnent. Report No. 8657-CHA, 1991.
 - 3 - (a) Access. Limited access to complete primary schools in poor and minority areas continues to be a constraining factor to rural education development in the nine project provinces Guizhou, Hainan, Heilongjiang, Hunan, Ningxia, Shaanxi, Shanxi, Sichuan and Yunnan. Schools offering full primary education programs are not always within reasonable walking distance from the homes of children in these areas. About 30 percent of the rural primary schools in project counties are incomplete schools, i.e., they do not offer the full primary program and some offer only three or even fewer grades. Small villages are served by "teaching points" which offer only two grades, 1 and 3 or 2 and 4: project counties currently have 10,093 such "teaching points". Since complete primary schools may be located 4-5 kilometers away from small villages and boarding schools are costly, many children tend to discontinue their education after attending an incomplete school, particularly girls from poor households. Improving access to primary schooling will require continuing efforts to provide better classroom and teacher capacity. (b) Poverty. Children from poor households are educationally disadvantaged, compared with those from wealthier households. Their enrollment, retention and completion rates are lower, and their dropout rates higher. The education gap in rural areas is largely caused by the inability of parents to afford the direct and indirect costs of schooling for their children. Data from the Household Education Spending (HES) survey (AnnexJ1) suggest that a household could spend as much as 20 percent of their annual income. Parents responding to the survey identified low incomes as the major reason for non-enrollment of their children. (c) Inequities. Gender disparity persists both in Han and minority societies: about 70 percent of the 7-11 age cohort who are not enrolled in schools are girls. This is more evident in eight provinces and autonomous regions which include Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Ningxia, Qinghai, Sichuan, Tibet, and Yunnan. A significant proportion of the population in these regions belong to national minorities and broadly reflects the relatively wider gender gap in enrollment rate among the minority groups. The completion rates for boys and girls in 1991-92 were 94.2 percent and 89.3 percent respectively with girls constituting about 75 percent of drop-outs from the primary cycle. While the literacy rate for male population of 15 years and older was 87 percent in 1990, it was only 68.1 percent for females. Sociocultural attitudes among some communities towards education of girls, the relatively poor recognition of the benefits of education for girls, school fees which constitute a substantial amount of meager resources, need to assist families with income-generating activities, and parental hesitation to send girls to co-educational schools without female teachers are some of the reasons for lower enrollment and retention rates for girls, especially those belonging to disadvantaged
 -4- population groups. The perceived lack of relevance of the school program to the future development and occupational needs of girls also have important bearing on attitudes to schooling. (d) Quality. Teacher effectiveness is limited. Nationally about 89 percent of primary school teachers meet State-prescribed qualifications: however regional disparities range from 94 percent in Liaoning to 49 percent in Tibet. The average figure for project counties at this time is 66.5 percent for primary school teachers and 33.4 percent for junior secondary. Training courses are historically strong on content and weak on the development of pedagogical skills. Few programs offer trainees instructional methodologies suited to rural schools nor provide skills for adapting the curriculum, prescribed teaching materials and equipment to local conditions. Courses in multigrade teaching and bilingual instruction, the latter required in minority schools, are not sufficiently widespread. This often emphasizes the cultural discontinuity between school and home, language of instruction and mother tongue. More than 37 percent of primary school teachers are minban (community supported) teachers, about 88 percent of whom are in rural areas. While significant efforts have been made to develop a training network to periodically reorient teachers to curriculum and methodological innovations, opportunities for in-service training for experienced teachers in poor, remote and minority areas continue to be inadequate. Teachers (and trainers) tend to be ill- prepared to meet the diversity of individual pupil needs. Science education in rural schools remains weak relying largely on rote memorization, and extremely disadvantaged in comparison with the modernized facilities, equipment and techniques available in urban schools. Consumable supplies and educational aids are either absent, or, if available, under-utilized. (e) Low Efficiency. Rural primary and lower secondary schools are more inefficient than their urban counterparts. This is evidenced by low student-teacher ratios, incomplete schools, low completion rates, and low girls' enrollments particularly in minority schools. A survey of 328 counties in 1992 found an inverse correlation between net income per capita and drop-out and repetition rates; the lower the net income, the higher the drop-out and repetition rates. Some estimates show that nearly one-third of the children who enter grade 1 in poor areas drop out before completing grade 5. Inadequately planned and managed teacher training programs, both at pre-service and in-service levels, especially in poor rural areas with relatively high levels of minority population, continue to hinder progress towards universalization. Generally, there are no mechanisms to identify efficiency-related issues and to provide and monitor corrective measures.
 (f) Inadequate Financing. Educational services which are seriously underfinanced and which provide inadequate schooling facilities in poor counties are a significant measure of urban-rural disparities. Buildings are in such poor physical condition that they are listed officially as "dangerous". In the Third Basic Education (Cr. 2831 -CHA) (BEIII) project counties, 6 percent of primary schools and 5 percent of junior secondary schools are officially listed as dangerous buildings. The school environment is not conducive to learning; bilingual instruction facilities are lacking in minority areas; costs of books have risen and instructional equipment is scarce. The average figure for project county schools meeting equipment standards for primary level is 52 percent decreasing to 32 percent for junior secondary schools. Distribution of teachers is uneven between urban and rural areas; the low pay of minban teachers in poor communities results in low motivation and a high turnover, resulting in instability. Although average annual increase in real expenditure has increased, most of this has funded teacher salaries and not better quality instructional inputs to provide an effective learning environment. (g) Weak Management Capacity. The reform agenda (see para. 1.4) has important implications for education management as Nine Year Compulsory Education implementation accelerates to meet goals set for 2000. Inadequate management capacity for planning, implementing, monitoring and evaluating reform programs for universalization of basic education poses difficulties in poor counties. Several tiers of government and administration are involved (central, provincial, county, village and educational institution) which make management tasks complex: appropriate structures are lacking to facilitate the systematic involvement and assistance of the community in the planning and implementation of primary education programs. While the SEdC management capacity has been strengthened since the preparation of the first basic education project, at a number of management levels there are shortages of qualified and experienced planners, data-processors, statisticians and analysts. Educational statistics and data on education financing, on school facilities, and on staff deployment are often incomplete or inaccurate and therefore provide insufficient information to identify and resolve efficiency problems such as wasteful student to staff ratios, low teaching loads, low utilization rates of facilities and equipment. D. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY, POLICIES AND PROGRAMS 1.6 The Central Government's approach to address the above issues and constraints is to develop broad principles and regulations to guide provincial and local governments developing their county and village level education services, so that they may implement the Compulsory Education Law using the resources available, and pursue their own targets, according to their own means. Principles to be encouraged at the national level
 - 6 - include access/equity, quality and efficiency: (a) access/equity issues include State efforts to subsidize economically undeveloped areas so that they may introduce, and where necessary, expand compulsory education and to encourage the transfers of funds from provincial to local governments; (b) quality improvement includes the introduction of newly developed sets of more relevant and adequate books for basic education, training of teachers to use the new text materials and provision of more pre-service and improved in-service training for teachers; and (c) efficiency is seen as increased cost-effectiveness in school management by reducing high repetition and drop-out rates, and adopting adequate student-teacher ratios and teacher workloads. 1.7 Government's Education Strategy for Poverty Areas. According to the Education Law, the most important basic law in education which became effective on September 1, 1995, the Government is charged with supporting and assisting the development of education for national minorities as well as remote and poverty stricken areas (Article 10). In keeping with the "Outline for Reform and Development of Education in China," the State Council issued detailed suggestions in 1994 on the implementation and planning for universalization of basic education, especially in poor areas, which has been undertaken on the basis of different timescales, according to the status of economic development as indicated in the following four categories: (a) Category 1: cities and selected rural areas with a fairly high level of economic development and covering 40 percent of the nation's population. Universalization targets in these areas are expected to be achieved by 1997. (b) Category 2: rural areas with medium level of economic development and covering another 40 percent of the population. This category has already achieved universal compulsory primary education and expects to meet nine-year targets by 2000. (c) Category 3: rural areas with low levels of economic development covering 15 percent of the country's population. For about 5 percent of this group, in areas with a good primary education system, the nine-year goal should be achieved by 2000. For the remaining 10 percent of this group, efforts will be made to implement five or six years of basic education. (d) Category 4: exceptionally poverty-stricken areas covering 5 percent of the population. Efforts will be made to implement three to four year primary education by 2000.
 - 7 - 1.8 In order to reach overall universalization of basic education, targets proposed by the State Council, SEdC will increase nonrecurrent categorical2 budgetary expenditures in all provinces with nationally designated poor counties so that they can achieve universal basic education by the year 2000. This is called the "Basic Education Program in Poor Areas" and funding will be used for school construction, provision of teaching equipment and library books, and teacher and principal training. 1.9 The special national fund established to finance the Basic Education Program in Poor Areas amounted to 200 million yuan in 1995, and, by 1997, the additional resources will amount to 800 million yuan. Between 1996-2000, SEdC will provide a total of 3.9 billion yuan to poor counties, with a matching 7.8 billion yuan expected from provinces and counties. The additional funds will be used for capital, nonrecurrent costs of improvement in school facilities, and the provision of equipment, furniture, and books. 1.10 The SEdC has adopted the International Development Association's (IDA) project preparation and management procedure in deciding what basic education projects to support with funds from the special fund and in managing the distribution of these funds to the provinces. The SEdC now requires that provinces submit applications for funds which are to be used in poverty areas, plans on how the funds are to be used, indicators on their use, with full annual review and reporting on outcomes. As Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, Guangdong, Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Jilin, Liaoning and Shandong have almost achieved the goal of universalization of nine-year compulsory education, SEdC is implementing the Basic Education Program in Poor Areas with a two-phase strategy: - Phase One (1995-98) focuses on Category 2 poor counties in the 12 provinces of Anhui, Fujian, Hainan, Hebei, Heilongjiang, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangxi, Shaanxi, Shanxi and Sichuan. These provinces account for approximately 40 percent of China's population. There are 289 "8/7 Counties"3 in Phase One with a population of some 110 million. The emphasis in Phase One is on junior secondary schooling. * Phase Two (1995 through 1998 to 2000 and beyond) will focus on Category 3 counties in the nine provinces and autonomous regions of Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Qinghai, Tibet, Xinjiang and Yunnan, accounting for some 190 million population. There are 273 "8/7 Counties" in Phase Two with a poor population of some 70 million. The government's strategy for Category 4 population areas is to include them in Phase Two. 1.11 Since the focus for Phase One provinces is the achievement of Nine Year Compulsory Education (NYCE), the proposed project will, compared with its predecessors, have increased emphases on junior secondary schooling (grades 6-9 the last three years of compulsory education). Taking situational realities into account, the project has been designed sufficiently flexibly to accommodate the varying priorities. 1.12 The Government's efforts include: (a) specially earmarked national funds for construction and rehabilitation of schools in poor areas; (b) upgrading the professional qualifications of minban teachers so that they can be converted to gongban (government supported) teachers; (c) specially targeted funds to support payment of charges for books, meals in boarding schools, and some transportation costs; (d) training of education managers at the provincial and county level in methods to achieve efficiency gains by using better resource allocation strategies and practices; and, (e) introduction of tax reforms which broaden and deepen the base for tax collection, earmark percentages for compulsory education, and allow for targeting of funds toward the poorer sections of the provinces. 1.13 Government Strategy for Minority Education. The evolution of China's strategy for the provision of education for ethnic minorities has undergone changes in the past four decades. For instance, in areas with large minority populations, there is increasing use of minority languages as the initial medium of instruction at primary level, with significant usage for classroom instruction although less widespread at secondary level. The percentage of local content in primary school textbooks has been increased, and levels of government-both local and national-support of teachers' salaries in predominantly minority areas have been increased. Also, since the 1970's there has been an increased recruitment of minority teachers and school principals, and greater efforts made to train bilingual teachers. 1.14 Government policy on minority education can be seen in a number of other systematic policy foci: (a) expanding access through: construction, expansion and renovation of township/village schools, teaching points and multigrade-schools; mandating universal 6-year education in all minority regions or an elementary graduate per household as a minimum requirement for remote and scattered rural inhabitation; development of a Center4 Elementary School for every township in each minority county and a Center Secondary School and a Literacy and Vocational Training Center for each minority county; (b) improving delivery and relevance of educational inputs by: 4 "Center" schools are generally town or county center level schools with additional faculty and funding provided by the province or county to act as inservice teacher and principal training, local curricula development and instructional equipment training sites.
 - 9 - improving teacher selection and preparation in pedagogy, bilingual education, curriculum revision and development of bilingual materials for minorities; and (c) increasing the resource base by developing preferential policies of increased national and provincial resource allocation targeted at basic education in poor minority regions for specific programs to reduce repetition and drop-out rates. 1.15 Government Strategy for Promoting Education of Girls. In the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Rights and Interests of Women," which became effective on October 1, 1992, the Government recognizes the education of girls as a societal responsibility. The Law states that: (a) "schools and departments concerned shall, by implementing the relevant regulations of the state, guarantee that women enjoy equal rights with men in such aspects as starting school, entering a higher school, job assignment upon graduation, conferment of academic degrees and dispatch for study abroad "(Article 15)"; and (b) "the governments, society and schools shall, in the light of the actual difficulties of female school-age children or adolescents in schooling, take effective measures to ensure that female school-age children or adolescents receive compulsory education for the number of years locally prescribed" (Article 17). 1.16 Several other measures have been taken to create a supportive environment for the promotion of girls' education. Legal protection for the rights and interests of women and girls is enshrined in the Compulsory Education Law and The Law Regarding the Health Care of Mother and Infants. The State Council issued the "Outline for Women Development in China" right before the UN Fourth Conference on Women in Beijing, and further highlighted the importance of girls' education to women's development and social status. Publicity drives have been initiated and the Chinese Government has expressed its determination to keep girls' dropout rate and lack of attendance to under two percent. Teacher training is being strengthened, especially for female teachers and principals. Social action in the form of financial assistance through the "Hope Project" and the "Spring Bud Plan" illustrate national efforts to help retain girls in school by lowering direct costs of schooling to parents. 1.17 In addition, a UNICEF-assisted project "Promoting Education of Girls in Poor Areas," started in 1992, is being implemented in selected townships in 101 counties in nine provinces (Anhui, Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Ningxia, Qinghai, Shaanxi, Sichuan and Yunnan). Specific strategies adopted under the project include, among others, campaigns to generate parental awareness of the benefits of girls' education and to overcome the socioeconomic barriers hindering participation of girls in education, mobilization of parents and community leaders in activities designed to enhance enrollment and retention of girls in schools, further increasing the proportion of trained female teachers and principals and incorporation into the school curriculum learning content that would enable girls to acquire the knowledge and skills relevant to their socioeconomic needs; specific measures implemented in minority areas of Ningxia include establishment of single-sex schools and single-sex classes and promoting participation of religious leaders in enrollment campaigns and school improvement
 - 10- activities. Activities under the proposed project would help in enhancing enrollment and retention of girls in the areas covered. 1.18 Assessment of Government Commitment. In addition to laws, policies, goals and achievement criteria outlined above, recent actions have confirmed the government's commitment to achieving universal basic education by the year 2000. In March 1995 the Chinese National People's Congress passed the new Education Law which confirms these ambitious goals for the year 2000 and directs the central, provincial and county governments to develop educational programs which will achieve the goals. The Bank preparation mission has reviewed the Government's Nine Year Compulsory Education Plan and the Education Law and is in fundamental agreement with their content, direction and intent. Over the last 15 years, processes and mechanisms established for planning, implementation and management of earlier education projects have helped to develop management capacity at the center and project provinces. This augurs well for the remaining preparatory work and implementation. The earlier basic education projects were developed and prepared within the same education policy context and the current project furthers and strengthens the Bank's support for the Government's program of improving China's Basic Education System. E. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 1.19 The Bank Group (IBRD and IDA) is in general agreement with the direction taken by China in developing its educational policies and system at all levels. It provides support to this process by maintaining a dialogue on sectoral issues and options, and by supporting selected activities which contribute to access/equity, quality and efficiency. In order to facilitate achievement of these ends, the Association's country assistance strategy in the education sector in China is to: (a) support basic education with particular attention to increasing access to quality schooling for the poor, minorities, and girls; (b) improve the effectiveness of teaching services including the upgrading of educational management, support services for principals and teachers, and teacher training; (c) assist in the design and implementation of reforms in the education sector, especially in seeking more equitable funding mechanisms, targeted to basic education in poor rural areas; and (d) support institution building to increase the capacity of educational authorities at all levels to carry out their responsibilities, especially under conditions of increasing operational decentralization. 1.20 Rationale for IDA Involvement. This proposed lending operation is consistent with the sector assistance strategy described above and the CAS discussed by the Board on March 18, 1997. In particular, the project will support the poverty reduction and human resources development objectives of the CAS, and will help the Government to implement the National Poverty Reduction Plan (8/7 Plan). IDA's ongoing support to China's efforts in improving basic education in poor and remote areas, including those inhabited by minority nationalities, has been effective in improving the design and implementation of such efforts. SUSTAINABILITY AND AFFORDABILITY 3.50 The project will partially finance school-based activities at the village, township, county and provincial level, and SEdC activities which are embedded within, and support the key national education policy of achieving universal 9-year education by the year 2000. In addition, the project will cover a small number of normal schools. The moderate level of IDA financing for the project (approximately 50 percent) and the annual levels of counterpart funding necessary for the project as a ratio of the actual 1995 provincial and county education budgets (0.89 and 3.3 percent, respectively, on average) increase both the chances for sustainability and affordability of the project activities. Additionally, the source of provincial counterpart funding is balanced and sustainable- on average approximately 35 percent from the county and 65 percent from the province and prefecture level. Likewise, the poverty reduction focus of the project is central to the Government's 7-year plan to eliminate absolute poverty by the year 2000, a plan that specifically aims at upgrading education and literacy in backward and poor areas. Built into the project are maintenance costs for schools, classrooms and equipment procured under the project, equipment procurement, technical assistance and training to develop a planning-enhancing MIS system. The training of approximately 130,000 teachers and school managers builds and strengthens existing and new human resource capacity which will remain in place after the implementation of the project. (See Anne I for detailed data.) 3.51 The financial sustainability of the project is assessed by comparing the projected total recurrent costs of compulsory education in project counties in 2002 with the projected recurrent budgets for compulsory education in these counties in that year. (See Annex 24 for detailed Economic and Financial Analysis.) Total recurrent cost in 2002 is the sum of the total regular recurrent costs of personnel and nonpersonnel inputs in 2002 and the total annual recurrent cost implication of the project. The total annual recurrent costs implication of the project is equal to the sum of the annual costs needed to maintain the effectiveness of project investments in school buildings, equipment, furniture, and technical assistance. In this analysis, the annual costs of maintenance of an education input is estimated to be the product of a coefficient for that input and the project investment in that input. The coefficient will vary across education inputs and across project counties. It is between 2 and 3 percent for school buildings, between 3 and 4 percent for equipment, between 1 and 2 percent for furniture, and between 0.1 and 0.3 percent for technical assistance. The projected recurrent budgets in 2002 were estimated on the basis of the actual recurrent expenditure in 1995 and a historical growth rate. 3.52 The final results of the analysis are incorporated in the revised feasibility reports prepared by the provincial representatives. The total annual recurrent cost implications of the project investment have been found to be a small percentage of the projected 2002 total recurrent costs at the provincial level. The aggregate results for the project counties are given in Annex 25. The project-related recurrent costs to be borne by the project counties are expected to be manageable.

This is a study of household education spending (HES) and access to basic education in four nationally-designated poor counties in China: Loufan and Liulin in Shanxi, and Luxi and Jiangchen in Yunnan. In 1995, HES was a heavy economic burden for a significant proportion of households. For example, for 22-40 percent of the households in the four counties, HES accounted for at least 20 percent of total household spending. And for 22-31 percent of the households in the four counties, HES accounted for at least 20 percent of household net income. 3. HES per child increased sharply with the level of schooling. In 1995, HES per child averaged 190 yuan for primary education, 482 yuan for lower-secondary education, and 1143 yuan for upper-secondary education. However, HES per child varied substantially across the four counties: it ranged between 117 and 269 yuan for primary education, between 272 and 1149 yuan for lower-secondary education, and between 464 and 3103 yuan for upper-secondary education. 4. Among the four counties, Luxi County in Yunnan had the highest percentage of children aged 7-15 years not in school. In 1995, 6.3 percent of boys and 20.0 percent of girls in this age groups were not in school in this county. Economic difficulty was the reason indicated by 61 percent of parents who provided an explanation for their children's absence from school. For the other three counties, between 2.4 and 4.2 percent of children aged 7-15 years were not in school. 5. In three of the four counties, parents have a higher desired level of educational attainment for boys than for girls. The majority of parents in all four counties want their children to have a post-secondary education. 6. For the majority of parents in Loufan, Liulin, and Luxi (counties with 0 to 37 percent minority population), their desired level of education attainment for their children is not economically attainable. In contrast, the great majority of parents in Jiangchen

HES usually increases with the level of schooling. The economic burden of HES can be assessed by determining the extent to which households have to devote their resources to schooling. Two common indicators are used: HES as a percentage of total household spending, and HES as a percentage of household net

 -72 - ANNEX7 ANNEX 7: PILOT TEXTBOOK RENTAL SCHEME 1. Rationale. Household spending on education is a heavy economic burden for a significant proportion of households in China, especially households from poor backgrounds. Surveys of households in several provinces in China have shown that such an economic burden is an important contributing factor to parents' decision not to send their children to school. Reducing the costs of schooling to families is a strategy for promoting access to compulsory education in China. In primary education, textbook costs constitute the largest component (30-40 percent) of household education spending at that level. Reducing the cost of textbooks to parents is thus a significant way of reducing household spending on primary education. The overall purpose of this pilot activity is to study the feasibility of the scheme and, if successful, to disseminate its findings in other poor areas within the provinces as well as other provinces. 2. Objectives. By reducing the cost of textbooks to parents, this project activity seeks to achieve three objectives: (a) improving access to compulsory education; (b) improving efficiency in the utilization of scarce resources; and (c) promoting students' discipline and care of books. 3. Organizational Arrangements. The textbook rental scheme will be piloted in 4 village schools in 2 counties in Shanxi Province under the aegis of SEdC and the PEdC. The Shanxi PEdC will be responsible for designing, implementing and evaluating the activity. The pilot will be organized as described below: 3 A Project Management Group (PMG) will have overall responsibility. It will comprise education researchers from the Higher Education Institute of Taiyuan Industrial University, education administrators from the concerned county education bureaus and the principals from pilot schools. The responsibilities of the PMG will be to develop the project action plan; train the operational staff; supervise the utilization of funds; ensure that the suitably protected (plastic, cloth) textbooks become available to students; monitor the progress of the pilot; and organize annual exchange of experience. The researchers from the University will be responsible for analyzing the results of the pilot and writing up the report. * A Project Implementation Group (PIG) will also be established. It will comprise pilot school principals, staff from the instruction divisions of the county education bureaus and pilot class teachers. The responsibilities of the PIG include awareness and information campaigns among parents and pupils, carry out the operational activities of the scheme, and collect, collate and document the results of the pilot.
 - 73 - ANNEX7 4. The guidelines for participating counties and schools include the following (details are available in project files): * parents pay for the full cost of a set of textbooks (about Y 70 per year in 1996) at the beginning of the school year; * at the end of the school year, parents return the textbooks to the school for a partial refund or credit towards the purchase of textbooks in the next school year; * the amount of refund or credit will depend on the condition of the returned textbooks to be determined by the PIG; * the school will re-issue the returned textbooks to students in the following year; and * the activity will be tried out in Grades 1-6. 5. Activities. (a) September 1997: Training for principals and teachers of pilot schools on running the pilot scheme; awareness campaigns among parents and pupils; new books will be wrapped with protective plastic covers; (b) February 1998: Review the utilization experience and cover new textbooks for the second school term; (c) July 1998: Collect all rental books, provide refunds as required, identify and record reasons for nonreturn books; (d) September 1998: Begin next round of distribution and monitoring of books; (e) September 1999: Review scheme, take note of damaged books, take decision on whether to continue with another cycle; (f) October 1999: Collate and analyze data from pilot schools; (g) March 2000: Complete the analysis and report. 6. Outcomes. Lessons will be learned on how to implement a textbook rental scheme. Reactions of parents, school personnel, students, administrators, and textbook publishers will be documented. Provinces will have the opportunity to discuss the outcomes and adopt such schemes if they are found to be workable. 7. Costs. The activity will be designed such that it will not affect the existing procedures in the production of textbooks. The personnel involved (in the pilot schools and in the County Education Bureau) will carry out this activity as part of their regular work. There will be some relatively small spending on book shelves, plastic covers, and
 - 74 - ANNEX7 materials for documenting the project activity. The funding will come from counterpart finds. 8. Monitoring and Evaluation. The Shanxi PEdC, with the assistance of researchers from Taiyuan Industrial University, will devise appropriate measures for monitoring and evaluating the scheme on the bases of the three objectives (para. 2). The evaluation will identify conditions that contribute to the effectiveness or otherwise of the scheme in each of the pilot schools. A report will be prepared for the Mid-Term Review. 9. Benefits. The activity will contribute to the identification of conditions for designing an effective textbook rental scheme. As indicated in the economic and financial analysis, the potential savings in textbook costs are substantial. The three objectives are all important benefits. Should the scheme pose implementation difficulties, important lessons would have been learnt about the sources of such difficulties. The investment cost is small compared to the potential benefits. 10. Risks. (a) Poor quality of paper; (b) Poor quality of plastic cover, offering inadequate protection; (c) Negative habits of pupils toward caring for books; (d) Some parents may not support the scheme, wanting to keep textbooks for review purposes; (e) Some parents' preference for new books for children; and (f) Frequent changes in textbooks which will undermine the effectiveness of such a scheme. 11. Sustainability. The State Education Commission will provide assistance in the dissemination of the findings of this pilot activity. If found workable where reviewed, both Project and nonproject provinces will have the opportunity to establish such schemes, adapting them as appropriate to suit local conditions.

 - 90 - ANNEX 12 ANNEX 12: TRAINING PROGRAMS FOR JUNIOR SECONDARY SCIENCE TEACHERS 1. Rationale. Qualitative deficiencies exist in teacher performance due to inadequate pre-and in-service training of science teachers. Teacher training has not kept pace with the curriculum changes in science and mathematics. It is imperative to re-train teachers through well planned inservice training programs in science teaching. The strategies and inputs set out below could be modified for initial teacher training programs. 2. Objectives (a) To improve knowledge and professional skills of junior secondary science teachers; (b) To improve the pedagogic skills of all junior secondary science teachers; (c) To provide high quality resources for inservice training of science teachers with special focus on school-based staff development; and (d) To promote initiative and innovation at school level through fostering cooperation between local schools in providing for their own staff development. 3. Strategies (a) Develop self-study training modules for science teaching in basic education with assistance from best available science educators; (b) Initiate a training of trainers program with specific roles assigned to teacher training institutions; (c) Establish a sustainable system of summer schools/inservice training using the modules as the main instructional material; and (d) Using self study modules, encourage the establishment of a school-based staff development system through pilots. 4. Inputs. SEdC's Teacher Training Department is preparing and trialing a set of training materials based on an evaluative survey of available teacher training resources. Apart from specially planned training programs, in order to improve the quality of
 -91- ANNEX 12 trainers who are to use the materials with their trainees, inputs should be estimated to provide the following: (a) Institutional responsibility for development of modules; (b) Panel of experts, comprising of both content and education technology experts, to write modules; (c) Trial and validation of modules; (d) Inservice training strategy involving county-based teacher support programs, summer schools or short-term inservice training, with clearly defined roles; and (e) One of the planned inservice inputs is a workshop for approximately 50 trainees to be held in May 1998 at Yunnan Agriculture University in Kunming, Yunnan Province. Trainees will include one international consultant and two local consultants. Details are available in project files. 5. Assumptions (a) This is a major effort, rather a movement, involving upgrading of science trainers and teachers to improve science education and requires careful planning. (b) Development of self study modules is crucial as through good learning resources average teachers' trainers could become more effective. (c) School-based staff development would ensure reaching out to a large number of teachers. Provinces and counties may want to assess the catalytic efforts of the primary level Teacher Services Network and consider the feasibility of establishing a network along fairly similar lines at the junior secondary level with a focus on science teaching. (d) Improving science teaching at the junior secondary science level is critical to the Government of China's reform plans for broad-based economic and social development. For the majority of rural junior secondary graduates, the program is the terminal point of their formal education experience. Key messages received and skills developed will have long-term spin-offs for agriculture, environment, income generation, occupational mobility, nutrition and general family health, to name a few outcomes. The existing centrally-planned curriculum includes much of this content but the majority of trainers nor teachers have the skills required to impart this to students.

The Teacher Services Network (TSN) will provide professional services which would support village level, school-based activities aimed at increasing understanding and knowledge of teaching and learning, improving pedagogical skills, and developing peer interaction to reduce professional isolation. The TSN will be piloted in two selected counties in each of the six project provinces. 2. Guidelines for Setting Up the TSNs. This Annex describes general guidelines to be considered when setting up the TSNs in the various provinces. They were discussed and identified during project preparation. In order to assess the practical working of such a Network, Yunnan Province will pilot a TSN in its Honghe region and some prefectures in Luxi county. (See project files for a detailed description of Yunnan's proposal.) Provinces will draw from the results of the pilot and the guidelines in this Annex as a basis for developing their own Network strategies. Irrespective of the specific organizational arrangements, professional support to village school teachers' problems and difficulties will remain the focal point of this activity. 3. Organizational Arrangements. The TSN will be developed along the following guidelines, with appropriate local variations: (a) TSN Centers (the Center) will form the hub of the Network and Town Central Primary Schools (TCPSs) in the twelve selected pilot counties will be designated as TSN Centers; (b) TSN Organizing Group. The TSN will be organized at the county level by a coordinating group comprising representatives from the prefecture level Normal School, County Teaching and Research Group (within the County Education Bureau) and the principal of the TSN Town Central Primary School. The Normal School representative will head this group which will ensure systematic planning, free flow of information and professional input. (c) The TSN Teachers' Group will be formed, comprising TSN Town Central Primary School principal (as head) and teacher representatives from the village schools and teaching points served by the Center. This group will identify and respond to teacher needs and liaise with the TSN Organizing Group to form a two-way dialogue channel (see Figure attached). (d) The Normal School Curriculum Review Group comprising the Vice Principal (Professional), the designated Head of Department who will oversee the TSN components and other appropriate faculty members. This

Activities (a) Immediate and short-term activities will include preparatory steps to be taken prior to the launch of the Centers: (i) a village school and teaching point level survey to identify the professional needs of teachers; (ii) the planning of a TSN Center Program based on the survey results; and (iii) the organization of an induction course on the TSN concept and relevance for TSN Organizing Group members; (b) Long-term activities would encompass the following: (i) dissemination of information pertaining to education policies, pedagogical principles, and techniques of cost-effective use of library books and instructional equipment and materials; (ii) annual monitoring of needs of village school and teaching point teachers to develop appropriate programs and activities; (iii) popularization of the production and use of low-cost teaching aids using locally available materials; and (iv) incorporation of village community contribution to develop a sense of ownership, responsibility and pride in the promotion of primary education in the community. 5. Teacher training is the linchpin in the Fourth Basic Education's program of expanding access to basic education, enhancing the quality of classroom teaching and ensuring cost-effective utilization of laboratories, equipment and library books. Objectives (a) To provide training which will focus on updating of normal school trainers training methods with special emphases on resource-aided, pupil-centered and activity-oriented methodology; (b) To review the minority component of the training curriculum with the aim of improving and expanding the content to suit local cultures and conditions, bilingual education programs where required, and multigrade teaching skills; (c) To provide effective human resources and institution management courses for principals and other administrative personnel; and (d) To provide 46 normal schools training and resources to enhance their inputs in the Teacher Services Network. 3. Since the Fourth Basic Education Project is an investment project in basic education in poor areas, the Association has attempted to quantify the economic impact of basic education in poor areas in China in two ways: the economic return of basic education for individuals, and the additional annual tax revenue for the local (county) government. Private Return to Basic Education 10. Researchers at the Institute of Higher Education, Peking University, were asked by the Association to estimate the economic return to basic education in poor areas in China. The dataset for this study contains information on 3,709 rural residents from 23 poor counties in the six provinces of Hunan, Hubei, Shaanxi, Shanxi, Yunnan, and Guizhou in 1991. Four of these provinces (Hunan, Shanxi, Yunnan, and Guizhou) are participating in the Fourth Basic Education Project. The analysis found that education and earnings were significantly and positively correlated. An additional year of schooling was associated with an increase of 4.75 yuan in monthly earnings, the average monthly earnings being 94.40 yuan. Using the elaborate method, it was found that the unadjusted internal rate of return was 8.98 percent for primary education and 11.24 percent for lower-secondary education. These findings show that investment in basic education in poor areas in China is quite profitable. Research in other countries has shown that education also has important social and political benefits, such as reduction in fertility rate, improvement in health, and contribution to national integration. Thus the case for investment in basic education in poor areas in China will be even stronger if these other less quantifiable benefits are applicable to China. Additional Tax Revenue 11. In China, the administration and financing of compulsory education (six years of primary education plus three years of lower-secondary education) is primarily the responsibility of local governments (governments at and below the county level). Residents in rural China pay a variety of taxes and levies to the county government, including rural education surcharges. Rural education surcharges are an established way for financing compulsory education in rural China. They generally amount to one to two percent of household income, with the precise surcharge rate determined locally. It is a national policy that the total tax/levy should not exceed five percent of household income. In addition, the poorest households (those under 400 yuan per capita per year) can be exempted from rural taxes and levies. Innovation in Student Assistance 17. Household Education Spending Survey. As part of the preparation of this project, a survey of households in four project counties was conducted. The survey was aimed at ascertaining the amount of household education spending, and assessing the economic burden of such spending and its impact on access to basic education for children from poor background. Two of the counties are located in Shanxi province and the other two in Yunnan province. Information from one hundred households in each county was collected by the socioeconomic survey teams of the State Statistics Bureau located in the concerned counties. The households were selected based on the sampling method used by the State Statistics Bureau in its annual survey of rural households in China. 18. Analysis of the survey data found that household education spending averaged between 13.7 percent and 20.3 percent of household net income. For 22-31 percent of the households in the four counties, education spending was a heavy economic burden. Among the four counties, Luxi County in Yunnan has the highest percentage of children aged 7-15 years not in school. For example, in 1995, 6.3 percent of boys and 20.0 percent of girls in this age group were not in school in this county; the economic burden
 -120- ANNEX24 of private costs of schooling was the reason indicated by 61 percent of the parents. There is a compelling need to reduce the economic burden of household education spending in order to encourage school attendance. 19. Student Assistance Program. The findings of the household survey lend strong support to the student assistance program initiated in the Third Basic Education Project. Both SEdC and the Bank Association agree that this innovation in student assistance should be continued as a component of the Fourth Basic Education Project. In fact, SEdC has requested and obtained additional funding from the Ministry of Finance for supporting a student assistance program. Between 1.6-6.2 percent of the counterpart fund of the various project provinces will be allocated to this component. The project provinces will develop guidelines for: (a) eligibility for assistance (including special treatment of poor female and minority students); (b) procedure for applying for assistance and evaluation of applications; (c) financing of the student-assistance fund; and (d) monitoring and management of the program. It is estimated that, at the primary level, the component will cover between 5.2-22.2 percent of the eligible primary students in the project counties annually. For all six provinces, the component provides financial assistance to 20,357 primary students per year or 11.0 percent of the eligible students. 20. The Association has made the following requests to the project provinces: (a) using a higher proportion of the interest proceeds from the fund on primary education than on lower-secondary education (say a ratio of 7:3); (b) giving higher priority to poor female and minority students; (c) using central student-assistance fund as seed money for the program; (d) developing a program plan for 1997-2002 (to indicate the coverage of poor students over time, and the financing sources); and (e) providing indicators to monitor the number of poor female and minority students receiving financial assistance. Piloting of a Textbook Rental Scheme 21. Cutting the costs of textbooks to parents is one way to reduce the economic burden of household education spending. The survey of households in four project counties also found overwhelming support by parents for a textbook rental scheme. According to a version of this scheme, a parent pays for the full cost of a set of textbooks (about 75 yuan per year) at the beginning of the school year. At the end of the school year, the parent returns the textbooks to the school for a partial refund (about 45 yuan) or credit towards the purchase of textbooks in the next school year. The amount of refund or credit will depend on the condition of the returned textbooks. The school will issue the returned textbooks to next year's student. A textbook is expected to last for three years. The textbook rental scheme actually has three objectives: (a) reducing the cost of textbooks to parents and thus the barrier in access to basic schooling; (b) improving efficiency in the utilization of a scarce education resource; and (c) promoting students' discipline and care of books. 22. During visits to schools in Hunan, Heilongjiang, and Hainan, the Association has also found support for such a scheme from school principals, teachers, and education

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Fourth Basic Education Project are: (1) to increase access/equity for the absolute poor in primary and junior secondary education, paying particular attention to girls and minority nationalities; (2) to enhance quality in primary and junior secondary schooling, and the corresponding teacher education and training of trainers' programs; and and (3) to improve efficiency in education delivery through improving educational management at national, provincial, county, and project institutional levels. The project components are: (1) to provide civil works construction, equipment, furniture, books and other instructional materials to primary and junior secondary schools in poor, minority, and remote areas; (2) to upgrade the professional content and practical skills of teachers and principals; and (3) to train education managers, and develop and utilize educational management information services.
